advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br> To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HOMO-COMPUTERUS</strong></font><br><blockquote>This image is from a brochure of a Dutch exhibition called "The office of the future" <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of the <b>Computer museum of the University of Amsterdam</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> EQUIPED FOR COMPETITION</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert (december 1984)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>March 1983 advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The big differences between the Epson HX-20 Notebook Computer (on the left) and the Apple Computer (on the right) are 1) the HX-20 doesn't need a power cord, 2) the HX-20 weights only about four pounds, and 3) the HX-20 costs a lot less money... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Prior to the 6800 computer, MSI manufactured 8" floppy disc units.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Arcades games in an armchair"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>Upgrade kit to transform a Spectrum into a Spectrum +<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DECEMBER 1972 HP JOURNAL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy <b>Joe Rigdon</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is for the Micromachine 4000, but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Speed serves business.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert tried to convince computers newcomers that a pocket computer could do the same as a desktop computer...<br><br><font color="#666666"> Now Texas Instruments brings you a cordless compact computer that solves the same sort of problems as the Apple or IBM Personal Computer...<br><br> ...For most personal computer tasks, its 6K RAM and 34K ROM are ample...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Dave Dunfield and his <a href="http://parse.com/~ddunfield/museum/index.htm" target="_blank">website</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This a classic Famicom clone system made in Asia...
It is quite small and was sold with two pads and two guns.
computer.keyboard: Two pads with 4 buttons eaxh + 2 guns
computer.name: JN-838
